name: Carnitine (L-Carnitine, Acetyl-L-Carnitine)
summary: An amino acid–like compound involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism, studied as a supplement for cognitive health, depression, and fatigue.
description: Carnitine is a naturally occurring compound derived from lysine and methionine. It plays a central role in transporting fatty acids into mitochondria for energy production. Supplementation is often used in two primary forms: L-carnitine, which supports muscular and metabolic health, and Acetyl-L-carnitine (ALCAR), which can cross the blood-brain barrier and may support cognitive function. Clinical research suggests potential benefits in depression, age-related cognitive decline, neuropathic pain, and fatigue syndromes. Carnitine supplementation is generally well tolerated, though some individuals may experience mild gastrointestinal upset or a 'fishy' odor due to metabolite excretion.

metadata.natural_source: Endogenously synthesized in liver and kidney; dietary sources include red meat, dairy, fish
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

contraindications: Seizure disorders (rare reports of increased seizure risk)

sections.text: Carnitine transports long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation, supporting ATP production. Acetyl-L-carnitine additionally donates acetyl groups for acetylcholine synthesis and crosses the blood-brain barrier, providing neuroprotective and neurotransmitter-modulating effects. These mechanisms may improve neuronal energy metabolism, enhance cognitive function, and reduce depressive symptoms.

adult.note: Often divided into 2–3 doses. Duration of 8–12 weeks studied in clinical trials.

sections.pediatric: Limited data; sometimes used in metabolic disorders under medical supervision

sections.text: Onset: 2–4 weeks. Duration: sustained with continued supplementation.

serious: Possible increased seizure risk in predisposed individuals

other: May exacerbate fishy odor in patients with trimethylaminuria.

items.risk: Carnitine may reduce thyroid hormone uptake

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient evidence; use only if benefits outweigh risks
sections.pediatrics: May be prescribed for inborn errors of metabolism under medical supervision
sections.geriatrics: Well studied for depression and cognitive decline

sections.text: Not required; no withdrawal or dependence reported.

items: Acetyl-L-carnitine has greater evidence for psychiatric and cognitive applications than plain L-carnitine.
May improve mitochondrial efficiency and reduce oxidative stress.
Meta-analyses suggest benefit for geriatric depression with fewer side effects than SSRIs.
